moves.1. e4: A normal, somewhat aggressive first move.
moves.1... e5: I generally have bad luck with the Sicilian so I like Open Game.
moves.2. Nc3: An interestingly defensive choice of knight movement.  This is more of a waiting move than anything, leading to the dangerous Vienna Game.
moves.2... Nf6: Black decides to take the Falkbeer Defense, challenging the d5 square.
moves.3. Bc4: White has nailed down the d-pawn by absolutely controlling the d5 square.
moves.3... c6: Alekhine recommends Nxe4 here - this move is rather timid and not terribly good.
moves.4. b4: More aggression, White is trying to assert control over the fifth rank.
moves.4... Bxb4: But White makes a bad blunder there and gets Black's bishop out of the back rank, in a strong and annoying position to boot.
moves.5. d4: Another, even worse move.  White is apparently trying to attack Black's center.
moves.5... Bxc3+: Black sees the undefended knight and the opportunity to check the king and fork the rook as well.
moves.6. Bd2: The most sensible move, White wants that bishop off the board.
moves.6... Bxa1: Bxd2 or Bxd4 might be good here, but getting a rook off the board on the sixth move is always nice.
moves.7. c3: White moves to trap the bishop in his corner; not the best move in the world since Qxa1 is available, though it does defend the d-pawn.
moves.7... Nxe4: More and more captures, leading to a weak White formation.
moves.8. Qb3: Prepping for a Bxf7, a really bad move as White should have other priorities.
moves.8... exd4: Castling might work here but Black has nothing to fear from the weak check and will keep harassing White.
moves.9. Bxf7+: White follows through. An attack, finally, although a weak one.
moves.9... Kf8: Forced, basically, as Ke7 pins in the queen and is asking for something bad to happen.
moves.10. Nf3: An attack on the center, White wants to bolster up his burgeoning attack.
moves.10... dxc3: There is more havoc to be wreaked; White's attack is still pretty toothless and Black is having fun here.
moves.11... Qe8: Rather a mistake, as Nxg5 was available, but it sets up a discovered check.
moves.12. Qb4+: An obvious move, Black thinks he can exploit the Black dark-squared bishop being involved.
moves.12... Kxf7: Clearly he forgot that the queen was the only defender of the light-squared bishop.
moves.13. O-O: Eliminates the discovered check and gets the rook into playing position; Black will take anything it can get.
moves.13... d5: Black sees his neglected queenside and angles to get some of those pieces going.
moves.14... h6: White does not have terribly many good moves here and attacks the bishop, which is a bit close for comfort.
moves.15. Be7: White appears to be evident on trading queens, though doing so at the cost of a bishop is high stupidity.
moves.17. Kf1: White has no idea what to do.
moves.17... Bb2: Black wants to promote his long-neglected pawn and is trying to protect the promotion square.
moves.19. f4: White did it, and Black can't promote.
moves.19... Nd2+: Rather the worse intermezzo.  Bh3+ would have been better.
moves.20... Bh3+: Black's caught on and will do it here.
moves.21. Kf2: Black either pins himself in the corner, loses his queen, or does this.
moves.22. Qe3: White finally wants to trade queens.
moves.23. Kxe3: Capturing with the rook would give direct promotion.
moves.23... Re8+: Oh well, the rook will go anyway with this skewer.
moves.25... c1=Q+: And White resigned, utterly lost.  I'm sure I made mistakes.  Have fun with this anyway.
